awd_titl_txt: Dispersion in Harmonic Analysis: Geometry and Boundary Conditions
awd_abstract_narration:
This mathematics research project is in the area of Fourier analysis: this is a branch of mathematics that plays an important role in the development of mathematical and physical theories. One aspect of the research pursued in this project provides the mathematical foundation for the study of light and sound waves. Fourier analysis continues to play a significant role in deepening one's understanding of the equations that model this behavior. In particular, these investigations yield further insight as to how the presence of a hard boundary surface influences the development of waves. For example, if one listens to the symphony in an auditorium, the sounds heard are affected by the manner in which the acoustic waves reflect off the walls. In this sense, it can be important to understand how the shape of the hall influences its acoustics. While this is, of course, a classical problem, there is more to be understood in terms of how these interactions influence dispersive properties. Moreover, this line of work is important in the analysis of closely related nonlinear equations arising from fiber optics, relativity, and water waves, where there is much to be done in understanding and limiting the various types of instabilities that can occur.  A second aspect of this research project seeks to understand the link between geometry and the behavior of vibrational modes.  This is closely related to so-called Chladni plates, where one vibrates a metal plate with sand on it and studies the patterns formed by the accumulation of sand, corresponding to the lines on which the plate does not move.  Here it is interesting to consider how the shape of the plate influences the patterns that evolve and to estimate their length.  These investigations are closely related to themes in quantum chaos and semiclassical analysis.

This mathematical research project in harmonic analysis seeks to understand dispersive properties of light, sound, and quantum waves in various settings such as in curved backgrounds, in nonhomogeneous media, and in the presence of boundary conditions.  These dispersive properties are, in turn, influenced by the behavior of paths of least action, so the approaches here rely partially on methods in microlocal analysis, where one seeks to understand such wave propagation in phase space.  This wave behavior can be modeled by solutions to partial differential equations, possibly satisfying certain boundary conditions.  Of particular interest is to understand how dispersive properties affect basic regularity estimates for solutions to these equations.  These regularity estimates actually stem from Fourier restriction theory, and in particular from the classical theorems of Stein, Tomas, and Strichartz.  While the non-Euclidean character of these problems means that the classical Fourier transform is not directly applicable, harmonic analysis is nonetheless fundamental to the proposed research.  Indeed, the common methods employed by the principal investigator for understanding wave propagation such as Fourier integral operators, the Hadamard parametrix, and wave-packet methods, rely on Fourier analysis to a strong degree. Moreover, the oscillatory integrals that arise in applying these methods are very close to those encountered in harmonic analysis, hence the research here deepens our understanding of the classical theory.

por.por_cntn:
The intellectual merit of the outcomes of this research conducted under NSF support concerned the mathematical foundations of wave propagation. The emphasis here was on mostly on stationary (a.k.a. standing) waves, that is, waves which oscillate periodically in time. A familiar example of these stationary waves are the fundamental tones associated to a vibrating string, which musicians often use to tune a stringed instrument. A two dimensional, and foundational, example of stationary waves are “Chladni plates”, where one takes a metal plate, dusts it with sand, and vibrates it in a manner so that it resonates at its fundamental tones. Early experiments were conducted by E. Chladni, who examined the linear patterns formed by the accumulation of sand in the process, corresponding to the lines on which the plate does not experience displacement (so called “nodal lines”). In such experiments, one can observe both that these patterns change as the frequency of the tone increases and also that the patterns change as the shape of the plate changes. The latter illustrates that it is interesting to consider the role of geometry in analyzing such stationary waves. 

Stationary waves arise in several disciplines, such as the problems in acoustics already suggested, but also in optics and quantum mechanics. The last of these is particularly notable since solutions to the time-independent Schrödinger equation naturally represent stationary waves or states. It should also be mentioned that more general wave propagation can often be understood as a sum of these stationary waves, providing further rationale for these investigations. 

The equations which model waves are examples of differential equations, where the solution that one seeks is actually a function depending on time and position (though for standing waves the time variable can be eliminated). The character of these equations is such that the derivatives, or rates of change, of the solutions in certain directions must satisfy certain relations. Hence the mathematical foundation of these equations connect with a field of pure mathematics known as real analysis. Real analysis has its origins in providing rigor to the core theorems of calculus. More generally though, its aim is to provide the groundwork for understanding functions of real variables and the operations on them, such as limits, differentiation, integration, and others. An active field within real analysis is Fourier analysis. This field, which originated in the work of Joseph Fourier on heat transfer, seeks to represent and understand general functions as an infinite sum or integral of trigonometric functions or perhaps other families of functions. As alluded to above, this type of analysis has proven to be effective for studying waves as well.

An underlying theme in the research performed here lies in analyzing and measuring how standing waves may concentrate their mass. In the case of the time-independent Schrödinger equation, this is significant as these regions of concentration reflect areas where a quantum particle is most likely to inhabit. Of particular interest is understanding this phenomena in the high frequency regime, or in the case of the Schrödinger equation, the semiclassical limit. One means of understanding and measuring this phenomena is to consider estimates of Lp type, where mathematically, one considers the integral of the amplitude of the wave raised to the p-th power. Such estimates have roots in Fourier analysis, where there are connections with classical problems concerning the Fourier transform. Since then, these Lp inequalities have shown to have broad applications, such as understanding the instabilities forming in nonlinear wave equations and estimating the length of nodal sets in standing waves. 

A significant outcome of the research performed here is a greater understanding of role of geometry in determining the best possible Lp inequalities. Another outcome has been an extension of the known Lp theory to cases where a potential function with critical scaling properties is included in the equation. Finally, these problems for standing waves do benefit from the analysis of related time-dependent equations, so another outcome has been a refinement of Van Vleck approximation, which relates to the time-dependent Schrödinger equation in the semiclassical limit. This approximation has already shown to be significant in the analysis of stationary wave problems, and it is anticipated that the viewpoint here will be impactful in such problems. 

The broader impacts of these activities include the training of students at the University of New Mexico. The PI is active in teaching, mentoring, and advising the diverse student population there. In particular, the PI advised a Ph.D. student in the department, who is now close to completing their dissertation in this problem area. Moreover, the PI has worked to refine and improve the graduate curriculum in real analysis, developing new courses to this end.
